availability.p: All research and writing of Civil War Governors of Kentucky Digital Documentary Edition annotations was undertaken by project staff, volunteers, and interns. Each record contains citations to relevant primary and secondary source material. All annotations are copyright Kentucky Historical Society, and should be referenced as such in any published work.

seriesStmt.title: Civil War Governors of Kentucky Digital Documentary Edition

body.p: Kentucky Soldier. Mercer County , Kentucky, native. Son of Thomas W. Fry and Elizabeth Fry. Attended Centre College in Danville, Kentucky. Graduated from Wabash College in Crawfordsville, Indiana, in 1840. Married to Mildred Smith on November 4, 1847. Married to Cynthia Fry. Father of Walker Fry, Thomas Fry, and Speed S. Fry. Admitted to the bar in 1843. Captain in the 2nd Kentucky Volunteer Infantry Regiment (U.S.A.) from June 9, 1846, to June 9, 1847. Veteran of the Mexican-American War. Merchant in Boyle County in 1850. County judge of Boyle County from 1857 to 1861. Colonel in the 4th Kentucky Volunteer Infantry Regiment (U.S.A.) from October 9, 1861, to March 21, 1862. Brigadier general in the Army of the Ohio from March 21, 1862, to August 24, 1865. Commandant of Camp Nelson.

ab.bibl:
Seventh Manuscript Census of the United States (1850), Population Schedules, Kentucky, Boyle County, District 2, p. 706.
Eighth Manuscript Census of the United States (1860), Population Schedules, Kentucky, Boyle County, p. 51.

Speed S. Fry and Mildred Smith, Kentucky, County Marriage Records, 1783-1965, Jefferson County, November 4, 1847.
Report of the Adjutant General of the State of Kentucky, vol. 1, 1861-1866 (Frankfort: Kentucky Yeoman Office, 1866), 628-29.
Report of the Adjutant General of the State of Kentucky, vol. 2, 1861-1866 (Frankfort: Kentucky Yeoman Office, 1867), 921, 960.
Report of the Adjutant General of the State of Kentucky: Mexican War Veterans (Frankfort: John D. Woods, Public Printer, 1889), 36.

Ezra J. Warner, Jr., Generals in Blue: Lives of the Union Commanders, (Baton Rouge: Louisiana State University Press, 1964), 163-64.
Richard D. Sears, Camp Nelson, Kentucky: A Civil War History (Lexington: University Press of Kentucky, 2002), 3, 111.
“Among His Comrades: Death of General Speed S. Fry at Soldiers’ Home,” Courier-Journal (Louisville, Ky.), August 2, 1892, p. 6.
